12.text: mining  in  the  Kookynie  area  began  in  1898,  and  official  Department  of  Minerals  and  Energy

13.text: statistics  record  500  923  ounces  gold  prior  to  1920,  with  the  largest  producer  being  the

14.text: Cosmopolitan mine, which produced more than 300,000oz of gold at a grade of 16 g/t Au.

24.text: The Money JV-Niagara North Project tenements occur in the strongly EW trending stratigraphy to the

30.text: The  geology  of  the  project  area  can  be  divided  into  three  segments  or  terrains;  a  northern

31.text: terrain of granitic and doleritic rocks, intruded at a relatively high level as exposed east of the Kookynie

32.text: township.  An  east-west  trending,  north  dipping  thrust  separates  this  terrain  from  the  two  southern

33.text: terrains; the Niagara Complex, a highly metamorphosed differentiated layered mafic intrusive and the

34.text: Mulliberry  Granite batholith. An interpreted NE trending,  north dipping thrust separates the Complex

37.text: Mineralisation at Niagara, directly to the south of the project area is associated with two east to east-

38.text: northeast  quartz  veins  which  cut  across  lithological  contacts  and  may  be  axial  plane  shears.  These

39.text: structures, which dip 50 to 80 degrees, are predominantly brittle but vary along strike from simple en

40.text: echelon quartz veins to brittle ductile shear zones containing irregular quartz veins. The most productive

41.text: zone was the southern containing  the  Lily  and  Mikado workings. Ore shoots at Niagara tend to pitch

42.text: east to southeast, dip south at 50 degrees, and have been  mined to  200  vertical  metres. Refer surface

text:
The Money JV-Niagara North Project tenements occur in the strongly EW trending stratigraphy to the 
 The  geology  of  the  project  area  can  be  divided  into  three  segments  or  terrains;  a  northern 
 terrain of granitic and doleritic rocks, intruded at a relatively high level as exposed east of the Kookynie 
 township.  An  east-west  trending,  north  dipping  thrust  separates  this  terrain  from  the  two  southern 
 terrains; the Niagara Complex, a highly metamorphosed differentiated layered mafic intrusive and the 
 Mulliberry  Granite batholith. An interpreted NE trending,  north dipping thrust separates the Complex 
 Mineralisation at Niagara, directly to the south of the project area is associated with two east to east-
 northeast  quartz  veins  which  cut  across  lithological  contacts  and  may  be  axial  plane  shears.  These 
 structures, which dip 50 to 80 degrees, are predominantly brittle but vary along strike from simple en 
 echelon quartz veins to brittle ductile shear zones containing irregular quartz veins. The most productive 
 zone was the southern containing  the  Lily  and  Mikado workings. Ore shoots at Niagara tend to pitch 
 east to southeast, dip south at 50 degrees, and have been  mined to  200  vertical  metres. Refer surface

13.text: a  bimodal  rhyolite-basalt  association  and  differentiated  dolerite  sills,  with  lesser  granodiorites  (the

14.text: ‘Melita  Greenstones’).  The  structural  setting  has  been  strongly  influenced  by  two  major  regional

15.text: structures; the Mount George shear, 15km to the west and the Keith-Kilkenny Fault, 40km to the east.

17.text: The  Melita  greenstones  may  be  assigned  to  the  Gindalbie  Terrane  and  are  interpreted  to  have  been

text:
a  bimodal  rhyolite-basalt  association  and  differentiated  dolerite  sills,  with  lesser  granodiorites  (the 
 ‘Melita  Greenstones’).  The  structural  setting  has  been  strongly  influenced  by  two  major  regional 
 structures; the Mount George shear, 15km to the west and the Keith-Kilkenny Fault, 40km to the east. 
 The  Melita  greenstones  may  be  assigned  to  the  Gindalbie  Terrane  and  are  interpreted  to  have  been

18.text: deposited at the eastern margin of a large rift basin which is now represented by the Kalgoorlie Terrane.

19.text: The greenstones are separated from andesitic volcanics associated with a volcanic arc further to the east,

20.text: by the Keith-Kilkenny fault (Barley et al., 1989).
